page.title: 01Historical Development.
page.content: { Sidmouth}is an outstanding example of the English coastal resort town as it developed during and after the Napoleonic Wars. Because it was not swamped by development in the later 19th Century, it is a relatively unspoilt example of its type and retains its essentially spacious character of a town of villas and terraces set in an outstanding landscape. The physical beauty of Sidmouth's setting is very impressive. The narrow Sid valley ends abruptly in a shingle ridge between huge red sandstone cliffs that rise to over 500 feet to the east and west. The relative steepness of these surrounding hills is vital to Sidmouth; it has kept the sea front free of building to the east of the Esplanade, providing a contrast of urban building with the red cliffs.
